articles.headline: Emails Detail Effort to Silence C.D.C. and Question Its Science
articles.snippet: Emails from a former top Trump health official and his science adviser show how the two refused to accept Centers for Disease Control and Prevention science and sought to silence the agency.
articles.abstract: Emails from a former top Trump health official and his science adviser show how the two refused to accept Centers for Disease Control and Prevention science and sought to silence the agency.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On June 30, as the coronavirus was cresting toward its summer peak, Dr. Paul Alexander, a new science adviser at the Department of Health and Human Services, composed a scathing two-page critique of an interview given by an experienced scientist at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
articles.byline: By Noah Weiland

articles.headline: Facebook Tried to Limit QAnon. It Failed.
articles.snippet: The social network tried cracking down on the spread of the conspiracy theory and other extremist material. But QAnon groups are still flourishing on the site.
articles.abstract: The social network tried cracking down on the spread of the conspiracy theory and other extremist material. But QAnon groups are still flourishing on the site.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Last month, Facebook said it was cracking down on activity tied to QAnon, a vast conspiracy theory that falsely claims that a satanic cabal runs the world, as well as other potentially violent extremist movements.
articles.byline: By Sheera Frenkel and Tiffany Hsu

articles.headline: How the Hero of ‘Hotel Rwanda’ Fell Into a Vengeful Strongman’s Trap
articles.snippet: Paul Rusesabagina went from the world’s most famous Rwandan to a prisoner of his political nemesis, President Paul Kagame, whose government accuses the coolheaded hotelier of murder, arson and terrorism.
articles.abstract: Paul Rusesabagina went from the world’s most famous Rwandan to a prisoner of his political nemesis, President Paul Kagame, whose government accuses the coolheaded hotelier of murder, arson and terrorism.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIGALI, Rwanda — As the manager of a five-star hotel where 1,268 people sheltered from the 1994 genocide in Rwanda, Paul Rusesabagina was known for his cool head — a quality that kept the killers at bay, helped ensure that all his guests survived, and led to an Oscar-nominated movie, “Hotel Rwanda,” that brought his story to a global audience.
articles.byline: By Abdi Latif Dahir, Declan Walsh, Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Ruth Maclean

articles.headline: A Deal on Drug Prices Undone by White House Insistence on ‘Trump Cards’
articles.snippet: The White House and the pharmaceutical industry were nearing a major deal to lower drug prices. Then the administration demanded that $100 cash cards be sent to millions of seniors before the election — and the industry balked.
articles.abstract: The White House and the pharmaceutical industry were nearing a major deal to lower drug prices. Then the administration demanded that $100 cash cards be sent to millions of seniors before the election — and the industry balked.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After months of heated accusations and painstaking negotiations, the White House and the pharmaceutical industry neared agreement late last month on a plan to make good on President Trump’s longstanding promise to lower drug prices.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: ‘It’s So Essential’: WeChat Ban Makes U.S.-China Standoff Personal
articles.snippet: When downloads of the Chinese-owned messaging service are barred in the U.S. starting at midnight on Sunday, the feud between the countries will hit home for millions of people.
articles.abstract: When downloads of the Chinese-owned messaging service are barred in the U.S. starting at midnight on Sunday, the feud between the countries will hit home for millions of people.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every day for nearly five years, Juliet Shen’s 94-year-old grandmother in Shanghai has begun her day with a WeChat message to her 40 children and grandchildren scattered across the globe.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi, Cecilia Kang and Kellen Browning

articles.headline: Justice Ginsburg’s Judicial Legacy of Striking Dissents
articles.snippet: She was part of the Supreme Court’s 4-member liberal wing throughout her 27-year tenure and led it in her last decade.
articles.abstract: She was part of the Supreme Court’s 4-member liberal wing throughout her 27-year tenure and led it in her last decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There was a framed copy of the Lilly Ledbetter Fair Pay Act of 2009 on the wall of the chambers of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, who died on Friday. She counted the law among her proudest achievements, even as it illustrated her limited power. As part of the Supreme Court’s four-member liberal wing, she did her most memorable work in dissent.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak

articles.headline: McConnell Vows Vote on Ginsburg Replacement as Her Death Upends the 2020 Race
articles.snippet: Democrats warn Republicans to follow the precedent they set in 2016, when they refused to consider President Barack Obama’s choice for the court on the grounds that it was an election year.
articles.abstract: Democrats warn Republicans to follow the precedent they set in 2016, when they refused to consider President Barack Obama’s choice for the court on the grounds that it was an election year.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg on Friday instantly upended the nation’s politics in the middle of an already bitter campaign, giving President Trump an opportunity to try to install a third member of the Supreme Court with just weeks before an election that polls show he is currently losing.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Trump Presses for New Justice ‘Without Delay’ as Election-Season Battle Looms
articles.snippet: The president is likely to nominate a successor this coming week to Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, who died on Friday, but Senate Republicans are weighing whether they have the votes to confirm his choice before the Nov. 3 election.
articles.abstract: The president is likely to nominate a successor this coming week to Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, who died on Friday, but Senate Republicans are weighing whether they have the votes to confirm his choice before the Nov. 3 election.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Update: President Trump has selected Judge Amy Coney Barrett to fill Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s seat on the Supreme Court.]
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Nursing Homes Oust Unwanted Patients With Claims of Psychosis
articles.snippet: They are finding what families say are pretexts to send patients to hospitals for psychiatric care — and then refusing to let them return.
articles.abstract: They are finding what families say are pretexts to send patients to hospitals for psychiatric care — and then refusing to let them return.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a New York nursing home, a resident hurled a bingo chip. At a home in Georgia, a 46-year-old woman, paralyzed from the waist down, repeatedly complained that no one had changed her diaper. In a California facility, a patient threw tableware.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Rachel Abrams

articles.headline: Shadow of Merrick Garland Hangs Over the Next Supreme Court Fight
articles.snippet: The fight over the confirmation of Judge Garland in 2016 set the tone for an even more brutal battle over who should succeed Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg.
articles.abstract: The fight over the confirmation of Judge Garland in 2016 set the tone for an even more brutal battle over who should succeed Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On a Saturday evening in February 2016, just hours after Justice Antonin Scalia died during a hunting trip, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican majority leader, interrupted a Caribbean vacation to draw a line in the sand.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Trump Approves Deal Between Oracle and TikTok
articles.snippet: The approval delays President Trump’s threat to block a popular Chinese-owned social media app, while the American software giant, Walmart and others try to complete a deal to take control.
articles.abstract: The approval delays President Trump’s threat to block a popular Chinese-owned social media app, while the American software giant, Walmart and others try to complete a deal to take control.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Saturday that he had approved a deal between the Chinese-owned social media app TikTok and major American companies, an agreement that will delay the U.S. government’s threat to block the popular app in the United States over national security concerns.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson, David McCabe and Erin Griffith

articles.headline: Joe Biden’s Court Vacancy Plan: More Talk of Health Care and the Pandemic
articles.snippet: Mr. Biden has spent months assailing President Trump’s handling of the coronavirus. With a bitter Supreme Court confirmation battle looming, he will seek to link the vacancy to the pandemic and the future of health care.
articles.abstract: Mr. Biden has spent months assailing President Trump’s handling of the coronavirus. With a bitter Supreme Court confirmation battle looming, he will seek to link the vacancy to the pandemic and the future of health care.
articles.lead_paragraph: For months Joseph R. Biden Jr. has condemned President Trump as a failed steward of the nation’s well-being, relentlessly framing the 2020 election as a referendum on the president’s handling of the coronavirus pandemic.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher, Katie Glueck and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: Voting Alone
articles.snippet: The national bard of community long warned about what isolation would do to us. Now our democracy is in the midst of an experiment no one asked for.
articles.abstract: The national bard of community long warned about what isolation would do to us. Now our democracy is in the midst of an experiment no one asked for.
articles.lead_paragraph: From his back deck in southwestern New Hampshire, Robert D. Putnam sees his yard slope past a few hardwood trees and an overturned canoe down to a pond, beyond which looms Mount Monadnock, one of Henry David Thoreau’s favorite peaks to hike.
articles.byline: By Marc Tracy

articles.headline: The Age of Electric Cars Is Dawning Ahead of Schedule
articles.snippet: Battery prices are dropping faster than expected. Analysts are moving up projections of when an electric vehicle won’t need government incentives to be cheaper than a gasoline model.
articles.abstract: Battery prices are dropping faster than expected. Analysts are moving up projections of when an electric vehicle won’t need government incentives to be cheaper than a gasoline model.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — An electric Volkswagen ID.3 for the same price as a Golf. A Tesla Model 3 that costs as much as a BMW 3 Series. A Renault Zoe electric subcompact whose monthly lease payment might equal a nice dinner for two in Paris.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing

articles.headline: With Flags, Crosses and Photos, Mourning 200,000 Dead
articles.snippet: Those left behind must grieve in a country still firmly gripped by the coronavirus pandemic. Everywhere they turn, there is a reminder of their pain.
articles.abstract: Those left behind must grieve in a country still firmly gripped by the coronavirus pandemic. Everywhere they turn, there is a reminder of their pain.
articles.lead_paragraph: Twelve days after his wife died of the coronavirus, increasing the enormous toll in the United States by one, Michael Davis, dazed and grieving, went back to work.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman, Serge F. Kovaleski and Jacey Fortin

articles.headline: ‘We May Be Surprised Again’: An Unpredictable Pandemic Takes a Terrible Toll
articles.snippet: At least 73 countries are seeing surges in newly detected cases, and in regions where cold weather is approaching, worries are mounting.
articles.abstract: At least 73 countries are seeing surges in newly detected cases, and in regions where cold weather is approaching, worries are mounting.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is a staggering toll, almost 200,000 people dead from the coronavirus in the United States, and nearly five times that many — close to one million people — around the world.
articles.byline: By Simon Romero, Manny Fernandez and Marc Santora

articles.headline: ‘There’s No There There’: What the TikTok Deal Achieved
articles.snippet: The agreement for the social media app falls short of President Trump’s promises.
articles.abstract: The agreement for the social media app falls short of President Trump’s promises.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The saga of TikTok had everything: Ominous threats of surveillance. A forced fire sale. Threats of retaliation. Head-spinning deal terms that morphed by the hour. Dark horse bidders and a looming deadline.
articles.byline: By Erin Griffith and David McCabe

articles.headline: TikTok Deal Exposes a Security Gap, and a Missing China Strategy
articles.snippet: Technological progress has outpaced the political debate again. What will happen when the next TikTok arrives in the United States?
articles.abstract: Technological progress has outpaced the political debate again. What will happen when the next TikTok arrives in the United States?
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has declared victory in his latest confrontation with China, saying that he headed off a looming national security threat by forcing the sale of the social media app sensation TikTok to a consortium of American, European and — though he does not say so — Chinese owners.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Trump and Democrats Brace for Showdown Over Supreme Court Seat
articles.snippet: The president’s determination to confirm a replacement for Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg before the election set lawmakers on a collision course as Congress deals with other major issues.
articles.abstract: The president’s determination to confirm a replacement for Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg before the election set lawmakers on a collision course as Congress deals with other major issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Update: President Trump has selected Judge Amy Coney Barrett to fill Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s seat on the Supreme Court.]
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Jeff Zucker Helped Create Donald Trump. That Show May Be Ending.
articles.snippet: The coziness between the TV executive and Mr. Trump is a Frankenstein story for the cable news era. But then the monster got away.
articles.abstract: The coziness between the TV executive and Mr. Trump is a Frankenstein story for the cable news era. But then the monster got away.
articles.lead_paragraph: In December 2015, after the demagoguery of Donald Trump’s presidential campaign became clear, I asked CNN’s president, Jeff Zucker, if he regretted his role in Mr. Trump’s rise.
articles.byline: By Ben Smith

articles.headline: U.S. and European Oil Giants Go Different Ways on Climate Change
articles.snippet: While BP and other European companies invest billions in renewable energy, Exxon and Chevron are committed to fossil fuels and betting on moonshots.
articles.abstract: While BP and other European companies invest billions in renewable energy, Exxon and Chevron are committed to fossil fuels and betting on moonshots.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — As oil prices plunge and concerns about climate change grow, BP, Royal Dutch Shell and other European energy companies are selling off oil fields, planning a sharp reduction in emissions and investing billions in renewable energy.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Head of Nikola, a G.M. Electric Truck Partner, Quits Amid Fraud Claims
articles.snippet: Trevor Milton, founder and executive chairman of Nikola, resigned after an investment fund accused him of making false assertions about his company’s technology.
articles.abstract: Trevor Milton, founder and executive chairman of Nikola, resigned after an investment fund accused him of making false assertions about his company’s technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: Trevor Milton, a college dropout, turned his entrepreneurial visions into Nikola, a start-up aiming to develop long-haul semi trucks powered by hydrogen and electricity. General Motors was so taken with the idea that it took a $2 billion stake in the company, even though it essentially has no revenue and has not produced a single truck.
articles.byline: By Neal E. Boudette and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: As School Begins, Mothers Working Retail Jobs Feel Extra Burden
articles.snippet: A number of women working in retail say they are being forced to choose between keeping their jobs and making sure their children can keep up with remote learning.
articles.abstract: A number of women working in retail say they are being forced to choose between keeping their jobs and making sure their children can keep up with remote learning.
articles.lead_paragraph: The start of the virtual school year has been a struggle for Patricia Reveles, a pharmacy technician at a CVS in Los Angeles, whose daughter is in fourth grade.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: Some Protests Against Police Brutality Take a More Confrontational Approach
articles.snippet: The protests are moving into white residential neighborhoods, where activists demand that people choose a side.
articles.abstract: The protests are moving into white residential neighborhoods, where activists demand that people choose a side.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Terrance Moses was watching protesters against police brutality march down his quiet residential street one recent evening when some in the group of a few hundred suddenly stopped and started yelling.
articles.byline: By Nellie Bowles
